definition.p: A subset U\subseteq\mb R is called open if and only if for every point x\in U, there exists an open interval (a,b) such that x\in(a,b)\subseteq U.

theorem.p: A subset U\subseteq\mb R is open if and only if there exists a collection of open intervals \mc U such that U=\bigcup\mc U.

proposition.p: Let x\in\mb R and S\subseteq\mb R. The point x is a limit point of the set S if and only if for every open set U containing x, there is a point y\in S such that x\not=y and y\in U.

theorem.p: The open subsets of \mb R satisfy the following properties.

ol.li: If \mc U is a collection of open sets, then \bigcup\mc U is also an open set.
If U,V are open sets, then U\cap V is an open set.

definition.p: Let X be a set, and let \mc T\subseteq \mc P(X) satisfy the following properties.

ol.li: If \mc U\subseteq\mc T, then \bigcup\mc U\in\mc T.
If U,V\in\mc T, then U\cap V\in\mc T.

definition.p: Then \mc T is called a topology on X, the pair \tuple{X,\mc T} is called a topological space, and elements U\in\mc T are called open sets of the space. (Usually \tuple{X,\mc T} is abbreviated to just X when the topology is known from context.)

theorem.p: Let X be any set. Then the following sets are topologies on X.

ol.li: \mc T=\mc P(X) is called the discrete topology.
\mc T=\{\emptyset,X\} is called the indiscrete topology.

proposition.p: Let \mc T be a topology, and let \mc U\subseteq\mc T be finite. Then \bigcap\mc U\in\mc T.
